The Shawshank Redemption continually abandons plausibility in order to celebrate the triumph of hope over despair, of decency over cruelty, of justice over injustice.
Without a single riot scene or horrific effect, it tells a slow, gentle story of camaraderie and growth, with an ending that abruptly finds poetic justice in what has come before.

At times poignant, joyful, and terrifying, Shawshank Redemption is an altogether brilliant movie and the debut of an equally brilliant director.

It's a devoutly old-fashioned, spiritually uplifting prison drama about two lifers who must break their emotional shackles before they can finally become free men.
When the film's conclusion starts to unfold, you suddenly realize that this is one of the more inspiring films you've seen in a long time - yet you don't feel the least bit manipulated.
It is able to sustain itself throughout its duration and to keep you enraptured with its remarkably hopeful story.

《肖申克的救赎》是一部非常经典的电影，让人们看了之后对人生有了更深刻的领悟。影片中所展示的人生经历和悲欢离合，使观众产生了共鸣。影片中，安迪·杜佛兄弟凭借自己的聪明才智与坚韧不拔的精神，成功逃出监狱并最终获得了自由。在这个过程中，他也体验到了人生的辛酸和孤独，这让观众们很容易就能从他身上看到自己的影子。这部影片告诉我们，在生活中，我们每个人都需要有那种不屈不挠的精神和勇气去追求自己的梦想和自由。即使我们遭遇到种种不公和困境，也不能轻易放弃，只有坚持到底才能获得真正的胜利。所以，这部电影对于观众的启示和感动是非常深刻的。

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a cinematic masterpiece that has stood the test of time. The film explores the harsh realities of prison life, including corruption, violence, and the struggle for survival. However, it also highlights the power of hope, friendship, and the human spirit. Andy befriends fellow inmate Red (played by Morgan Freeman), and the two form a bond that lasts throughout their time in prison and beyond. Robbins and Freeman deliver outstanding performances, capturing the depth and complexity of their characters. It is a visually stunning film, with sweeping cinematography and powerful imagery that captures the bleakness of prison life.

The Shawshank Redemption is widely regarded as one of the greatest movies ever made, and it's easy to see why. Directed by Frank Darabont and based on a novella by Stephen King, the film is a powerful meditation on hope, redemption, and the resilience of the human spirit. The movie tells the story of Andy Dufresne, played by Tim Robbins, a man who is wrongfully convicted of murder and sent to Shawshank State Penitentiary. In prison, Andy forms a friendship with fellow inmate Red, played by Morgan Freeman, and sets about using his intelligence and resourcefulness to survive and even thrive in the brutal and oppressive environment of the prison. One of the strengths of The Shawshank Redemption is its nuanced portrayal of the characters. Andy and Red are complex and multifaceted individuals, and their friendship is depicted with a depth and authenticity that is rare in Hollywood films. The movie also features a talented supporting cast, including Bob Gunton as the sadistic Warden Norton and William Sadler as the troubled and tragic Heywood. But perhaps the greatest strength of The Shawshank Redemption is its message of hope and redemption. Even in the darkest and most hopeless of circumstances, the movie suggests, there is always the possibility of redemption and the potential for a better future. Andy's determination to survive and maintain his humanity in the face of incredible adversity is inspiring and uplifting, and the film's ultimate message of hope and renewal is both moving and profound. Visually, The Shawshank Redemption is also a masterpiece. The film's cinematography and production design are both striking and memorable, and the use of music, particularly the haunting and beautiful score by Thomas Newman, adds to the movie's emotional impact. Overall, The Shawshank Redemption is a powerful and deeply moving film that resonates with audiences on a profound level. Its themes of hope and redemption are universal, and its message of the transformative power of human connection and resilience is one that will continue to inspire and uplift viewers for years to come.

The movies that were called the dark horse of the industry were unexpected and impressive movies that will stick in your mind for a long time. A drama film called Shawshank Redemption is the story of a banker, Andy Dufresne, who was caught up in the murder of his wife and her adultery then. Their story is about the rest of his life in the Shawshank prison, the friendship, and the pain of reality. One of the most interesting parts of this movie is that it is told from a third-person point of view, which gives a new perspective by using an indirect approach. It depicts a lot of inequity in prison life, but the focus point in this movie is hope. The hope that could rarely be found in a place that was called "hopeless," such as prison, is the reason why the movie wants to show freedom in ways that people could never have imagined that people in prison would still have hope. This is not the normal prison film that audiences expect about jailbreak, but this movie leads to a different feeling. It's gained emotion through the situation that the characters have been through, and even more emotion is gained by the impressive ending. The movie always showed you some phases that demonstrated the truth of being human; that will definitely hit you. You will be able to relate a scenario, a character, or a situation in this simple movie to something deeply personal in your own life after experiencing it. This kind of movie is great to keep watching more than once because your thoughts and perspective on it will change as you grow up. Shawshank Redemption could of course be called an encouraging film, and that is also the aim of the director, but in my understanding, this film is bittersweet and more bitter than sweet. Because the character's pain is shown a lot in this film, the key is how he deals with the situation and how it would be if there were a condition in the situation. But what is beautiful is the strong relationships that exist in this place, and you will feel that while watching it. Along with great performances from actors like Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins, it was one of the best. But there are also live support acts that are absolutely brilliant and impressive. Although most of the scenes of the film take place in a tense place. I would recommend this movie for the two and a half hours that it is worth for people who want to experience a simple but golden movie story like The Shawshank Redemption. You will even more clearly understand why this movie is the highest rated on IMDB. However, I recommended this movie to older teenage audiences because some of the content in the movie is violent, and the context of that content will become clearer to this generation or older. Finally, The Shawshank Redemption offers you a variety of experiences that will definitely give you brilliant pleasure.

"The Shawshank Redemption" is an absolute masterpiece of filmmaking. This timeless classic tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a man wrongfully convicted of murder who finds hope and redemption in the form of friendship at Shawshank prison. With stunning performances from Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman, this film masterfully blends drama, humor, and hope to create a movie experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll. The direction by Frank Darabont is flawless, and the script, adapted from a Stephen King novella, is nothing short of brilliant. If you haven't seen "The Shawshank Redemption," do yourself a favor and watch it. It's a truly fantastic movie that should be on everyone's must-see list.

It's no wonder that this uplifting, well-crafted masterpiece is still considered one of the best films in cinema history.

Possibly the best movie of all time, the realism of this movie causes us to feel empathy for people who the general population think are just scum. This movie shines a light on inmates and endites the penal system with the character of Brooks, who is a perfect example of the true horrors of prison. since watching The Shawshank Redemption, I have not watched a movie with a better ending. I wholeheartedly believe that this movie has the most ingenious plot. The story is told so that we don't really realise what is happening until it has happened, but when we realise we can only marvel at the quality of scriptwriting. This movie feels like every single word is chosen specifically to build to something, absolutely everything that happens in this movie is relevant to the ending and that is what makes this movie so good. Although this movie isn't as gut-wrenching as The Green Mile, it still has some very emotional scenes. There is truly nowhere that this movie falls down; the cinematography is 10/10, the writing 10/10, and the ending 1000/10. I can truly not oversell how incredible this movie is. Bravo Darabont, truly the master of prison movies!
Brilliant story fantastically acted. My favourite film of all time.

There's very little that needs to be said other than watch this immediately. The acting is incredible with deep chemistry and dialogue. The editing and pacing are incredible telling the story but also delivering the timeless message of never losing hope as it is what makes us human. What's amazing most of all is how the film never feels overly sentimental or tugging at the heartstrings to make up for a lack of substance. I used to think this was a perfect movie, without a single flaw. However, when watching it on high definition tv, the background on the roof scene is obviously green screen. I never noticed this back in the day on a standard definition tv. Other than that, yes, it's a perfect film. The coolest thing about this movie is the ending. 99 other directors would have ending the movie as Red rode the bus down to Mexico, leaving us to assume he eventually met up with Andy. The decision to actually show the embrace on the beach brought it all together and perfectly concluded a nearly perfect film. Cinematic masterpiece. It will never be outdone.

Man who appreciates prison drama says: "The Shawshank redemption is a classic and a brilliant movie about friendship and hope. Wow, well that's totally accurate. I wholeheartedly agree. I can fondly recall really fun rainy afternoons as a kid spent watching this very friendly and life affirming film. Whenever, people have let me down or I lose help in people which has happened quite a few times in my life. This particular film encourages me to believe in the power of perseverance and the rewards that can come after you have endured, and let's sincerely observe Andy Dufresnes' unfortunate vicissitudes of circumstances he does a lot of waiting for a crime he didn't commit and doesn't deserve to pay for obviously. Finally, I have not been there for others either this film speaks to me(mind you in a very cerebral way)and says: "people are capable of terrible atrocities but they are also capable of fantastic achievements and acts of goodwill".(that last quote is a monologue reverberating in my mind.

The Shawshank Redemption is an eminently watchable prison drama featuring great performances, especially from Tim Robbins, Morgan Freeman, and Bob Gunton, gorgeous cinematography from Roger Deakins, and a clever script which does a brilliant job of adapting Stephen King's novella. Like Gene Siskel, I noticed many similarities to One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, with themes of abuse of authority and society's mistreatment of its most vulnerable members, but Shawshank is more hopeful about our ability to progress and eliminate these abuses. Whether or not the film's belief in humanity's capacity for redemption is realistic, the rays of hope which permeate what otherwise could have been an exceptionally bleak film make it much more approachable.
Always watch when the opportunity arises. A near-perfect film.

Thoughts upon watching this film in 2022: It has the aura of a fairy tale. The prisoners, hard core as they may be, are like mythical creatures: Morgan Freeman as the kindly convict, James Whitmore as the tragic librarian, and Tim Robbins as the soft spoken but conniving Andy. None of them are realistic. They're romanticized. But we're captivated by them thanks to a great screenplay and strong performances. It's a man's movie. This was obvious the first time I watched it. I thought women might have a hard time relating to it. But after my recent viewing, I realized that a great story transcends gender issues and has universal appeal. William Sadler, in an early role, gives a strong supporting performance. Roger Deakins is, without doubt one of the finest cinematographers in the history of film. His camera work in this movie alone could be an entire class in film school. There are so many improbable scenes, like the beer drinking scene on the roof and the scene in which Andy broadcasts an opera record over the prison P.A. It's sheer romanticism—and we eat it up. Clearly, Andy is a Christ-like figure. It's a story that never fails. His "death" is his sentence and the beatings he takes in prison. His "resurrection" is his prison break. He does good for his brethren, but he has no mercy on the warden. The corrupt and hypocritical warden represents the money changers in the temple, and Andy, in righteous anger, overturns his table. The denouement of the film ties in nicely with an earlier mention by Andy of Robert Frost. The poem in question is "Mending Wall." Those who have read it will understand. Lastly, I've never understood why this film, now regarded as a masterpiece, was a box office failure. What were people thinking in 1994? Or maybe they weren't thinking.
This movie is so good, I cried a few times. My top prison movie.
This movie is perfection. Plain and simple. Nothing more, nothing less

Warning: Spoilers Shawshank Redemption is without doubt one of the best films ever made, and definitely the best film of 1994. Yes, it is better than Lion King, and I really like that too. It is not only enthralling but powerful and moving too. I will confess that I didn't understand it when I first saw it as a lot happens in the film, and I have now seen it three times. I seriously hope, that those who ignored the film when it was first released now recognise it as a great film, as it really is. The dialogue was extremely well-written, with lines that really stick in your mind. The cinematography and music are both gorgeous, and the prison itself is like a character that dominates the film. In the script, there are some true elements of Stephen King Now I admit I am not a huge king fan, and usually don't like coarse language in books. But in his books like It, which is very good, I have accepted the language represents brutality and rebellion, shown perfectly in the film with the battle of acceptance I suppose between the inmates and the superiors(like the scene with the warden yelling coarse language at the new inmates lined up in a row at the beginning.)The acting was exceptional. I am not hugely familiar with Tim Robbins, but he did a great job in a very demanding role. The best performance however, comes from Morgan Freeman as Red, who was seriously robbed of that Oscar, that he lost to Tom Hanks for Forrest Gump. Freeman reminds me very strongly, or his style of acting does, remind me of that of Sean Connery, suave yet very charismatic. Acting isn't just about your vocal range, it's about depth, which was what Freeman certainly had. In short, Freeman was brilliant in what could be his best performance. The scene where the inmates are listening to the Mozart aria over the speakers was a beautiful profound moment, and I actually cried in Brook's death scene. Very rarely do King adaptations translate-to screen well, because of the large scale of the author's books, with the exception of this and the Shining. Some like It and Dreamcatcher are genuinely memorable but have a number of flaws that prevent them from being classed as outstanding. And some, like Thinner and Tommyknockers that border on unwatchable. In conclusion Shawshank is a brilliant film, that is worthy of the credit it has been denied for so-long. 10/10 of course. Bethany Cox.

Few movies in this world are as powerful as The Shawshank Redemption. This well-crafted drama drags your emotions through the wringer, only to have them come out clean & full of hope on the other side. The story is unquestionably compelling and absolutely memorable. In addition, Tim Robbins, Morgan Freeman, and the rest of the cast create a collage of authentic characters that you both love & hate. This is a film that everyone should watch at least once a year to remind themselves of how good it really is.
Tim Robbins makes this movie, after some S & M committed on this guy he starts to make friends with the Warden and Some Police working the Jail, but he gets his revenge after he gets out of Jail.
It speaks to the power of this movie that it's been one of my favorites since I was five years. Even a young child can see the power off this story.

For a long, long time I wondered what was really going on. 9.3 out of 10 possible points on the world's largest film database IMDb, even before classics like The Godfather Part 1 and 2 and leader of some best lists. Yet it's just about a convicted banker who befriends Morgan Freeman and gets used to his life as a prisoner in Shawshank men's prison. But there's a lot more to this film than the blue-eyed setting up of modern movie clichés. For the crux of The Shawshank Redemption already lies in its ensemble. Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman as the leading men in their absolute prime as actors. Secondary characters that integrate ideally into the scenarios of the protagonists and all have essential functions as their companions. Villains that seem generic from today's point of view, but for those times were unparalleled in cruelty. All of these ingeniously written roles have a hand in the plot, none of them feeling superfluous at any point. Of course, the film's trump card is the chemistry between Robbin's character Andy and Freeman's Red. After an initial distance, the two grow closer and closer as the film progresses, and within the nearly 30 years over which the plot takes place, they become almost inseparable. A down-to-earth and simple male friendship, where both of them share a terrible fate. How the two manage to carry each other through the cold harshness of prison life is gripping to follow. The individual scenes mainly belong to Robbin's Andy. This one is characterized by Red's over-voice and while this movie tool works in very few cases, it's a bull's eye here. It's not for nothing that Freeman's voice is considered iconic to this day. You have from the start that a man is telling his friend's story. Freeman's screen time suffers a bit as a result, but it doesn't take anything away from what is arguably the best performance of his career. Robbins delivers the much quieter and subtler performance, while Freeman excels in empathetic and even comedic monologues and dialogue at times. The rest of the cast adds to an all-around perfect ensemble performance. Foremost among them is Bob Gunton as the corrupt Warden Norton, under whose hypocritical posturing as a sensible Christian lurks a malicious layer that lends the film some (necessary) devastation. Whether The Shawshank Redemption is really the best film of all time is debatable. However, one thing can't be denied: From an objective point of view, it is without major weaknesses. If anything, the slightly pathetic and conventional ending actually fits seamlessly with the previous plot. In this respect, this is perhaps a point of criticism, but merely one without much significance. Otherwise, it's a film that still did a lot to me at 22 years old, even 27 years later. The sensations of pain, shock and happiness regularly catch up with you. Despite its epic running length and slow build, the film is always entertaining and engaging, and it's also beautifully directed and photographed. Hard to find any flaws here.

Based on the novel written by Stephen King, The Shawshank Redemption is a story about the redemption of humans. The story follows a man named Andy Duphrane who is accused of murdering his wife and the man she had been cheating with and is sent to the Shawshank prison where he becomes friends with another criminal named red. Starring Tim Robbins, Morgan Freeman, John Sandler, and Clancy Brown, the movie has an excellent cast that knows how to deliver a masterpiece. The story is written in a way that makes the audience care about them and their plight. The highlights of this movie are the costume design and setting within the prison. It captures the feel of the prison incredibly well and makes you feel like you're actually in 1947. The score by Thomas Newman is just as wonderful as always as he delivers an emotionally powerful and heart-wrenching soundtrack. The Shawshank Redemption is a wonderful movie that knows where it shines and a brilliant movie that knows exactly how to tug at the heartstrings of the viewer, with phenomenal writing, cinematography and score. This movie knows how to pull off an excellent screenplay. I recommend this movie to anyone who hasn't seen it before, and even if you have, revisit it, you might even notice something you didn't before.

What a satisfying and beautiful film. The story is unique and engaging, with plenty of humor and heart without losing sight of its tragic situation. I love that the movie didn't focus much on Andy trying to prove his innocence - he knew he was innocent, and so did we, and we also both knew there was no point in trying to prove it. Once you're in Shawshank, it doesn't matter who is innocent or guilty, and that's part of what makes this film so powerful. The characters are flawed and grow throughout the movie, and the ones we lose along the way are truly heartbreaking. My only complaint with this one is that we see a 20+ year stretch for all of these characters, yet only the main ones seem to age at all, and even those effects are questionable at best. It took me out of the film occasionally every time I noticed it. But keeping in mind that this is over 30 years old at this point, it's a pretty minor gripe. This film is astounding regardless.
What can I say about this that hasn't already been said? An absolute timeless classic. If you haven't seen this, I suggest you stop what you're doing right now and go watch it.

Simply a film that's impossible to dislike. The first time i saw it (a long time ago), I felt that it was technically good, but it didn't grip me. On recent subsequent watches, not only does it hold-up, it actually gets better!!!

I won't spend a lot of time waxing poetic about the virtues of this movie - everyone knows it's among the greatest of all time. What could one even criticize? The narration was the highlight, followed closely by the screenplay, then the cinematography. Morgan's performance was obviously very good but he's since replicated it in other movies, so it wasn't mindblowing, but still God-tier. The only thing wrong with this movie is that it didn't achieve supreme box office success from word-of-mouth; 1994 was an incredibly strong year for movies.
Beautiful movie with an uplifting story that is believable and magical at the same time. It is a must see with a message of hope.
Wonderful movie with great lessons for life and brilliant-written characters.
My favorite movie of all time!!

"Get busy living, or get busy dying" It's very reflective that this quote is so central as a theme that it is the basis that guides the actions of each character. Andy never loses hope and he really "gets busy living", because he knows that as long as his mind is free and as long as he has still hope, he will never really be a "prisoner". The success of the screenplay and the dirctor can be found in having perfectly managed to arouse complete empathy in the viewer towards a prisoner like Red, who has never denied his actions and who, thanks to Andy, has understood that the conditional release will never be what will make him free, but the awareness, of no longer being that man capable of killing other human beings, has led him to be truly free. It's quite a pity that Morgan Freeman didn't get an Oscar or a Golden Globe for his performance, however he had to contend with a Tom Hanks who brought one of his most famous performances to theaters: Forrest Gump. In conclusion, "Shawshank Redemption" is a masterpiece that everyone should see at least once in their life; despite its duration, it is very discursive and never heavy. Final grade 10/10
